Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2009 10:03AM Carmelle wrote: Heather, sorry that you have all this going on...as far as the ovaries out it is immediate menopause and opens up the aromatase inhibitors as an option. I did have one BC person I know of who kept progressing on Tamox and finally had ovaries out and had the first remission of her disease in years. She took Arimidex after the ovary removal. Good luck with your decision. Know of another stage 4 who was 10 years remissions after ovary and aromatase. So it can work.

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2008 09:24AM Carmelle wrote: Thanks Ladies for all of your well wishes. I am truly thankful for everything including the support I've received here over the past 5 years. I'm glad it has helped to hear. I always let people know that for me I was diagnosed at 38 a year after my childhood friend was diagnosed at 35. She was stage 3C. Had chemo first before surgery as her tumor was very large and had pulled in her breast, and still had 4+ nodes even after chemo. She was Her+ and er- and all the bad omens. We both had babies & young children. She is now 6 and 1/2 years and has gorgeous long hair and the biggest smile. Michelle

Posts.Title: STABLE!! Fitztwins MJLToday

Posts.Content: Carmelle wrote: Well I'm at the five year mark. I know that it's just a mark and the risk still remains but honestly didn't think Id' see this and till be all clear five years ago. The past few years (after treatment) have truly been the best of my life. I don't wait to do...I do what needs to be done now. Spend time with my family, travel, work at my career, work on maintaining my health. Expanding my views as a person. I don't post much anymore except here and the Canadian site but wanted to share for newcomers as I always looked to see what was possible when it was so hard to believe. Michelle Yesterday is History... Tomorrow is Mystery...Today is a gift. Dx 3/7/2003, IDC, 6cm+, Stage IIIA, Grade 2, 5/15 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: 5 years this week. Carmelle sue_m

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2008 04:21AM Carmelle wrote: I developed radiation pneumonitis about 5 weeks after rads ended in 2003. fatugue, pain on inhale, rib pain, cackling dry cough, fever and then vomitting. I toughed it out for 4 months...misdiagnosed with bacterial pneumonia. Mine took a good long dose of prednisone to clear up 75mg/day for about 3 months. I still have pain (pleurisy) in my right lung to this day.Pain was a big symptom for me. Michelle

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2008 09:36AM Carmelle wrote: i had bilateral mast and rads. about 18 months later implants. i did not have expansion and stuck to and A/B cup implant with a one-step surgery. I did have other issues with the rads side and was not able to have successful nipple surgeries. tried both skin flap and skin graft and both failed but i did have tattoos last year and wow...what a difference.

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2008 09:44AM Carmelle wrote: I am not stage 4 but have the same er+/pr-/her- as your mom and have been treated with Arimidex for the past 4 years. The post above with the ATAC trial info shows that this particular er+ pr- combination does very well with an aromatase inhibitor but not as well with Tamoxifen. I was 38 but had ovaries removed and thus qualified for the AI. Your mom is lucky to have you looking out for her. Michelle

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2011 09:51AM Carmelle wrote: I too had too many surgeries and things during the first year and a half. I postponed until about two years after. I did have some complications and several more surgeries to repair. I did not do for cosmetic reasons but for other more unexpected feelings. I found that having the weight and feel of my chest back helped me to forget. Also after bilateral with no fat or skin on chest it was always having to wear something so clothes wouldn't sag or gap open. I swim and bathing suit was a pain etc. Then after several more years I had the nipple tattoos. Really had to brace myself for these things. Resent the invasion after so much time has passed. The outcome is not beautiful, nor would I pose for any calendar but it looks Ok and once again helps me forget. When i step out of shower and catch a glimpse in mirror it doesn't remind me anymore. Not vanity but jsut wanting to put it behind...move on.
